oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Site of old forge
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unkown
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Hugh C. Leighton Co. U.S.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard showing monument on site of forge used in Revolutionary times. Colorized. The forge was known as Brewster's Forge. The forge was used to make some of the links in the chain that was placed in the Hudson River to stop the British in the Revolutionary War. The stone was erected by Quassaick Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution of Newburgh, N.Y. 1901.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Monuments; Revolutions;
Orange County - New York
Military;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission required to use any image from the digital collections of the Cornwall Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Firthcliffe Carpet Mills, Firthcliffe, N. Y. ; Colorized. Firth Carpet Mills was the main employer in Cornwall, New York, for many years. The mill was in business from 1886 until 1962.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: FIRTHCLIFFE CLUB, Firthcliffe, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The owners of the Firth Carpet Company built the clubhouse for their employees. The first floor had a pool and billiard room and reading and card rooms. The second floor had a gym and dance floor. The basement had bowling alleys. In 1917 movie pictures were shown. In 1921 John Robert Smith opened a barbershop in the clubhouse. The clubhouse was large to enough for 200 people to attend the dances. The Christmas party in 1938 had 1,000 people in attendance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Clubs; Clubhouses; Dance; Leisure; Recreation; Sports & recreation facilities;
Daily Life; Community & Events; People; Recreation; Work & Labor; Sports;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission required to use any image from the digital collections of the Cornwall Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Up the Hill, Firthcliffe, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: These buildings were part of the Firth Carpet Company community in Cornwall, NY. The large building was the post office and the smaller building on the left was Anna Smith's general store. In the left background is a view of the train station. The mill was down this street and to the right behind these buildings. The large building is still there and is a private home.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard. This school was built in 1906 of red brick with cement and light stone trim. The building is on Willow Avenue in Cornwall, New York. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: This old house was occupied by Lafeyette and used as Pay Station during the Revolutionary War, near Cornwall, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This house was located on Forge Hill Road, New Windsor, New York. Forge Hill Road runs between Highway 9-W and Highway 32. In front of this house was a forge used by Mr. Brewster to make parts of the chain that went across the Hudson River during the American Revolutionary War to try to stop the British from going north from West Point.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mattheissen Square, Cornwall-on-Hudson, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Evard Matthieson built the first housing development in Cornwall-on-Hudson. All the houses were two-story victorian style houses. The houses were for sale beginning October 1913. Prices ranged from $1650 to $2600. The architect was Adam B. Jaeger; contractors were Mead and Taft and Mr. William H. Garrison; the plumber was Henry Hahn.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presbyterian Church, Cornwall-On-Hudson, N .Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On March 5, 1856, the first structure at 222 Hudson Street, Cornwall-on-Hudson, was completed by Daniel Taft, a renowned builder in the area. Records say the building was capable of seating 350 people. The first congregation of church members had originally been members of the Canterbury Church in Cornwall. They disagreed on the matter of slavery and broke away from Canterbury to establish a less rigid church.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Churches; Religion;
Cornwall-on-Hudson - Orange County - New York;
Architecture; Religion; Landscape & Nature;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission required to use any image from the digital collections of the Cornwall Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Klein's Cash Grocery and General Store, Cornwall Landing, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The grocery store was established in 1835 by Nathan Clark . The business was purchased by Samuel Klein in 1914. Cornwall Landing was one of the busiest harbors on the Hudson River. The Landing had many thriving businesses from the early 1700s until the 1960s. The word "cash" is misspelled on the front of the store. It is spelled "Cach". The lady is dressed in the style of 1850.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Clothing & dress; General stores; Grocery stores;
Cornwall-on-Hudson - Orange County - New York;
Daily Life; Business & Industry; Work & Labor; Architecture;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission required to use any image from the digital collections of the Cornwall Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presbyterian Church, Cornwall, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Known as the Canterbury Presbyterian Church, it was erected in 1827 of stone and with a coating of stucco. It is located on Clinton Street, Cornwall, New York.

Canterbury Presbyterian Church

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: River Lighthouse, Cornwall-on-Hudson, N. Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The large two-story house was originally part of the land owned by the Sands family. The estate was called "Evergreen" and owned by Clementine Talmadge, a daughter of Catherine Sands Ring. In 1911 the house was owned by Mrs. Emma Hardy who presented the house to the New York Association for the Blind who used it for a summer place for blind people to experience the mountain air.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Norwich
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Museum of the City of New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of the longest-lived wooden vessel, the Hudson River steamboat, Norwich, was a passenger boat and a ferry, but was better known as a tugboat and an icebreaker. She was so successful at breaking ice, she was known as "The Ice King".

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Idlewild, the residence of N.P. Willis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Idlewild was built by N. P. Willis in 1852. The style is Gothic "built of brick and covered with a lime wash". It was designed by Calvert Vaux with a central hall from which opened a parlor, dining room, library, bedroom and staircase hall. Upstairs were several bedrooms,two with dressing rooms, all with closets.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This high school is on Willow Avenue. It was one of two high schools in Cornwall and Cornwall-on-Hudson in the 1900s to the 1940s. The building was built in 1906 with three floors and a basement. It was built in the colonial style of red brick with cement and light stone trim.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: E. & H.T. Anthony & Co., 501 Broadway, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the Moodna Creek just before it joins the Hudson River, near Cornwall-on-Hudson, New York. There are four men and a rowboat on the south side of the creek. The water is calm, so there is no wind, so the men may be going fishing or just enjoying being outside in a pleasant place.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This fire house is located on Hudson Street in the village of Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY. It was built in 1903 by contractor George Stevenson, Jr. for $4,740.00. oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of Cornwall from Storm King Mountain. To the left is Moodna Creek. Straight ahead is Plum Point and to the right is the Hudson River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hudson Street, Cornwall-on-Hudson, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unkown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This view of Hudson Street in the village of Cornwall-on-Hudson is looking southeast to Storm King Mountain. The building on the right side is near Duncan Avenue. There is a sign advertising ice cream and candies. Further along is a sign advertising "telegrams". The tower of the Storm King Fire Company can be seen in the distance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Villages;
Cornwall-on-Hudson - Orange County - New York;
Daily Life; Community & Events;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Matthiessen Hall, Cornwall-on-Hudson, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This three story building was erected in 1870 by the Cornwall Library Building Company at a cost of $28,000 for land and construction. The first floor contained a bank, drug store, and post office; on the second floor were offices, a billiard room and the library; the top floor was a hall seating four hundred with a gallery at one end and stage at the other. The library contained several thousand volumes; magazines; and daily and weekly newspapers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architecture; Buildings; Concert halls; Libraries (Rooms);
Cornwall-on-Hudson - Orange County - New York;
